subject: Re: [junit] handling test reports
msgSnippet: If the developers run all of the tests each time they check in (rather than waiting for the nightly build), then they know immediately which tests they have
messageBody:
If the developers run all of the tests each time they check in (rather than
waiting for the nightly build), then they know immediately which tests they
have broken and which they are responsible for fixing. If you have 100
tests failing on a typical night, something needs to change about the
process!

Our current project has 1040 "regular" JUnit tests that run in about 10
seconds. So the developers run all of them all day long after everything
they do. As soon as one of them breaks, we fix it right away. There are
another 200 or so tests that take a little longer (some use Catcus on the
server side, some use database connections). These run automatically when
anyone checks in (kicked off by Cruise Control) , so within 10 minutes of
submiting code to the repository, you know whether you have broken any of
these "integration level" tests.

Once the norm becomes all of the tests passing (rather than 100 failing),
the nature of your problem may change. This is a much more scalable
approach than trying to manage/distribute failure reports.

Jeff Nielsen
Digital Focus

From: "yair fine" <yair_fine@...>
To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Wednesday, August 06, 2003 5:12 PM
Subject: [junit] handling test reports


> Hi ,
> I have a general question , and it is more of a design issue.
>
> Currently , i am involved in a java project that has 3 people working on.
> We have somthing around 2000 junit tests running on a nightly build basis
,using ANT.
> The nightly build proccess ends with a mail report that has the summery of
the tests
> reports , and has a link to a directory , where all tests reports are
bundled.
> I mean , in the mail there is something like :
> 1900 tests succeed , 100 tests failed ..
>
> I also have a small util that can scan these reports and look for a
specific string ,
> like "Page Fault occured" , and add a reference to specific test report
and line number.
> That way each developer of the 3 , can look at the mail summery , and
search if there is
> any problem related to his part of the project.the summery is not too long
or complicated
> to look in .
>
> This strategy works fine in this quantity of tests and developers.
> What happens if I want to expand these nightly build tests 10 times more.
> Now , the project involves 30 developers , divided into sub teams.
> If i use the currnt format of reporting , i will get very big logs of
,2000*10 =
> 20000,tests .And big mail summery that contain information that does not
interest every
> one.
> rpoblem 1:
> James , is in sub team A , and he wrote
com.company.pkg.testConcernsToJamesOnly
> and Rachel , is from team B , and she wrote
com.company.pkg.testRachelTests
> James don't want to see Rachels tests reports or mail summery , he don't
want to get lost
> in a big amount of data when he looks for his results.
> is there a way to split outputs , according to packages ?
> i.e, James's tests result will be sent to a differnt log file.
>
> problem 2:
> In a week , Rachel is going to be fired ( don't tell her that...)
> I want all reports and mail summery that rachel got , will be sent to her
successor.
> is there a way to create a connection between users and tests packages?
> i.e , now com.company.pkg.testRachelTests belong to George (the new guy
replacing Rachel)
> ,
> and for James too, for two weeks only,
> and com.company.pkg.testConcernsToJamesOnly still belongs to James
>
> I thought of maybe a configuration file that has notification list :
> _________________________________________
> James
> com.company.pkg.testConcernsToJamesOnly
> com.company.pkg.testRachelTests
>
> George
> com.company.pkg.testRachelTests
> _________________________________________
>
> but how do i implement this .
> does JUNIT / ANT support stuff like that?
> this is a real life issue
> regards
> Yair
>
